block.p: Re ''For N.F.L. Draft, the Biggest (XXXXXXL) Sleeper,'' April 25: Walter Thomas may turn out to be a great player in the N.F.L., but at what price?

After recent articles in The Times profiling former N.F.L. players who have Alzheimer's after sustaining head injuries, it seems absurd to put another 370-pound player on the field. The league should calculate the future medical costs of these clashing Goliaths.
Re ''For N.F.L. Draft, the Biggest (XXXXXXL) Sleeper,'' April 25: Walter Thomas may turn out to be a great player in the N.F.L., but at what price?

After recent articles in The Times profiling former N.F.L. players who have Alzheimer's after sustaining head injuries, it seems absurd to put another 370-pound player on the field. The league should calculate the future medical costs of these clashing Goliaths.

Then there's the issue of how many calories need to be burned to keep someone like Thomas running as fast as he does. He is probably just a little less fuel efficient than his Ford Expedition. Not that the N.F.L. will ever care about anything besides ticket prices, licensing and the cost of a 30-second ad, but the conspicuous consumption the league promotes is as antiquated as a leather helmet.
